question: Which is evidence that the Canadian workforce is largely a <image 1>?
options: ['Job opportunities are increasing for highly skilled jobs.', 'Job opportunities are decreasing for mid-level jobs.', 'Highly skilled jobs pay better than low-skill jobs.', 'Women tend to make less than men do for the same job.']
description:
The image is a black-and-white cartoon depicting two contrasting scenarios related to education and success. On the left side, there is a child named Jim with an IQ of 150, standing on a tall stack of books labeled "Enrichment Programmes," "ISO-Certified Tutors," "Best Books $ Can Buy," "Latest IT Tools," and "Education." Jim is reaching up towards a carrot labeled "SUCCESS" hanging from a string. Two adults, one holding a bucket labeled "Double-Boiled Tonic," are cheering him on, saying "GO JUNIOR, GO!" and "GO, SIR!"

On the right side, there is another child named Seng, also with an IQ of 150, standing on a single book labeled "Basic Education." An adult is scolding Seng, saying, "STOP MAKING EXCUSES, YOU'RE JUST NOT WORKING HARD ENOUGH!" Another adult is telling Seng, "LATER AFTER SCHOOL MAKE SURE COME HOME TAKE CARE OF AH GIRL, AH!"

The cartoon suggests that despite having the same IQ, Jim has access to numerous resources and support, while Seng has limited resources and additional responsibilities at home. The artist's signature "JoshC 27/4/10" is in the bottom right corner. 

This image does not provide any direct information about the Canadian workforce or job opportunities. It focuses on the disparity in educational resources and support between two children with the same IQ but different backgrounds. Therefore, none of the options A, B, C, or D can be directly inferred from this image.
